title: I was wondering if it would be possible to get gambling debts eliminated in a chapter 7 as business debt?
question: Unfortunately, I have amassed a great amount of gambling debt, and my wife and I currently make too much money to be able to pass the means test for a chapter 7. However, I was wondering if gambling debt can be classified as business debt and be wiped away with a chapter 7. Or if there's a better approach to the debt. Any insight is greatly appreciated. Thanks.
question_tags: Business debt,Business litigation,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Consumer debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Filing a lawsuit
answers:
If you left a "marker" in any Nevada casino, how you classify the debt on your bankruptcy is irrelevant. You will go to jail for not paying a casino marker in Nevada as it is classified as a bad check offense. Unless you have paid an attorney to run your means test numbers, you may not be aware of the loopholes to the Means test aside from classifying debt as business related. More information at the link below. Hope this perspective helps!

The Good Faith Test
https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/the-good-faith-test---the-only-thing-you-need-to-know-about-qualifying-for-chapter-7-bankruptcy

I'm not sure why making this a "business" debt matters. If you consider this your self-employment business, you are filing a personal chapter 7 anyway and gambling debts are usually dischargeable (see below). If you are trying to include this in an LLC or Corporate filing, those entities do no receive a discharge in chapter 7. You might be a personal co-debtorin that situation and could owe the debt personally anyway. You need to consul with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to sort this out.

Also, in at least one case that I filed, the District Attorney in a Nevada county claimed that the debt was not dischargeable because it was a criminal offense. The casino has the person sign a "check" and then when the check was bad (as it usually was) and the client's bank didn't honor it, the casino reported it as a "bad check" to the DA. The DA then prosecuted it as a crime under a NV statute. If you have something like that, I recommend also talking to a criminal attorney in Nevada also before filing.

I agree with my colleagues that gambling debt is not consumer debt so that won't help you with the issue regarding the means test. Perhaps you need to consider a chapter 13. Meeting with an experienced bankruptcy attorney who does chapter 13 cases would be time well spent to consider your options.

Even though I practiced for years in area where I had to travel by almost a dozen casinos to get to work every day, I never thought about gambling debt being non-consumer debt. Looking at the definitions of consumer and non-consumer debt, I think you may have a shot.

A consumer debt is defined as “debt incurred by an individual primarily for personal, family, or household purpose.”

A debt is not a consumer debt is a debt that is not for a personal, family, or household purpose. Generally non-consumer debt is that which is incurred for business purposes. “Business debt” is a debt incurred with a “profit motive”, a business purpose, or investment purpose. When you were gambling, I assume you were doing that, planning to beat the casinos. If so, you had a profit motive.

There are other non-consumer debts that are not business debt, the most common being tax debt.

I imagine that the United States Trustee in your area would contest your assertion that gambling debt is a non-consumer debt. Thus, you need to find an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles litigation in bankruptcy court. Use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to begin your search for an attorney.

I am doubtful that you can discharge gambling debts as "business" unless you are a professional gambler. The Means Test is not applicable to a debtor whose debts are "primarily business debts". You should set up an appointment with an experienced BK lawyer who can personally evaluate your financial details and outline your options.
